page.title: 15Taunton Cider. History.
page.content: Taunton Cider was established at Norton Fitzwarren in 1911. Before this, the Rev. Cornish had established a reputation for the drink at Heathfield Rectory. In 1921 the firm was registered and has since expanded from six workers to over 500. The French grew cider apples in Normandy and used to import them through Weymouth. The need arose to process the apples before delays ruined them and this was achieved by concentrating the juice. Until 25 years ago this was used to produce 'Nat', a draught cider in wooden casks sold within a 70ml. radius of Taunton. The pagan custom of 'wassailing' has recently been revived at Taunton Cider. In January a Wassail Queen is carried around a cider apple orchard giving a token gift of toast soaked in cider to the robins in the trees.
